title: Interpreting and Steering LLMs with Mutual Information-based Explanations on Sparse Autoencoders
author: Xuansheng Wu (University of Georgia), Jiayi Yuan (Rice University), Wenlin Yao (Amazon), Xiaoming Zhai (University of Georgia), Ninghao Liu (University of Georgia), ...
relevance_why: The paper discusses novel methods to interpret and steer Large Language Models (LLMs) using explanations derived from sparse autoencoders, which could be applicable to text-to-audio or audio-related generation tasks requiring nuanced control.
background: The paper focuses on developing methods for interpreting and modifying the behaviors of Large Language Models to improve control and safety in responses.
contribution: This paper introduces mutual information-based explanations for learned features in sparse autoencoders to enhance discourse-level understanding and steer LLM behaviors effectively.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods largely extracted surface-level linguistic patterns leading to limited explanations.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work overcomes the frequency bias by utilizing a fixed vocabulary and mutual information to ensure more meaningful discourse-level explanations.

key_innovation: Utilizes a structured approach to derive explanations that capture semantic meanings rather than just frequent linguistic patterns.
real_world_impact: Enhancements in understanding and steering LLMs can improve safety and reliability in applications such as automated customer support and content generation.
limitations: The approach builds upon existing sparse autoencoders, which may still inherit some frequency bias.

new_terms.sparse autoencoder: **Sparse autoencoder** is a type of neural network designed to learn a representation of data that includes many zeros in its output, focusing on capturing unique features.
new_terms.frequency bias: **Frequency bias** refers to the tendency of previous interpretation methods to prioritize commonly occurring linguistic patterns over less frequent but semantically important concepts.

open_sourcing: The authors have committed to releasing the code and data upon acceptance.
